body:
I experienced this also. Artifacts are logged to a local directory on my client, instead of on the server as expected.

The logic in [artifact_repo.py](https://github.com/mlflow/mlflow/blob/v0.8.2/mlflow/store/artifact_repo.py#L95) doesn't have any case for HTTP, and this is the function used by [client.py](https://github.com/mlflow/mlflow/blob/v0.8.2/mlflow/tracking/client.py#L162). It appears the expectation is that if you run client and server on separate hosts, you should use one of the protocols that are covered.

Thanks a lot for the information @dstine. I tried to circumvent the issue with SFTP and it more or less works. I had to add a config entry for my ssh key though. (`private_key_pass` in  [sftp_artifact_repo.py](mlflow/mlflow/store/sftp_artifact_repo.py) as workaround)

Unfortunately my artifacts are not shown in the UI. On the start page of the experiment it says `Artifact Location: sftp://user@host/home/username/mlflow` But when I click on the date of a run I get `Oops, something went wrong...` from mlflow UI. (The tutorials show a nice UI https://www.mlflow.org/docs/latest/tutorial.html of course.)

Does this problem relate to the sftp path?

I assume that when I use sftp it should be neither on the client nor on the hot running server but on a third host accessible to both client and server.

The artifacts are logged to the URI specified by `--default-artifact-root`. If you pass a local path to it, it will log artifacts to that local path. See [documentation](https://mlflow.org/docs/latest/tracking.html#storage) and #810.

I think the logic that store at local is not convincible, because you already have a artifact at local, and in the code just use shutil.copy() to store at another address (same machine).
I think should use the logic same as log_metric that sent rest to remote machine if set_tracking_uri is http and default-artifact-root is None or file path.
Thanks.

> I think the logic that store at local is not convincible, because you already have a artifact at local, and in the code just use shutil.copy() to store at another address (same machine).
> I think should use the logic same as log_metric that sent rest to remote machine if set_tracking_uri is http and default-artifact-root is None or file path.
> Thanks.

I think that is why I got confused in the first place. I set the remote tracking and thus expect to see all logged items on the remote machine and not locally.

@maoding 

My team is running into this artifact crashing MLFlow issue as well. We are in an Azure environment using Databricks and Azure Data Lake for artifact storage. Our process is to generating an artifact, store in the Lake, and logging it with log_artifact. When we go back to look at the visuals generated(artifacts), clicking on them brings us to the Niagara Falls error page. Did you all ever find a solution for this?

Hi @Gabriel808,

I am sorry I think I cannot help you since I haven’t used this in an Azure environment. But I guess setting the right credentials for the store on Azure is essential. Read up on this here https://mlflow.org/docs/latest/tracking.html on the Azure section.
This issue has been automatically marked as stale because it has not had recent activity. It will be closed if no further activity occurs. Thank you for your contributions.

I too think that the behavior of the `log_*` functions is rather inconsistent, without built-in support for uploading larger artifacts such as models to the server side (which is the whole point of experiment tracking - preserve the artifacts to put them in production without refitting). 

For instance H2O uses separate menu options and/or API functions for remote and local actions (download / upload vs import / save). NFS is not remote as it has to be mounted locally on the client side... One needs yet another server apart from mlflow server or else our most important artifacts will be dispersed in local users folders, siloed, passworded, or manually deleted as the ./mflow folder is not even hidden...

Compared to H2O, where one can upload data to a training server and then download trained models from the server, even using a browser, without any scripting (and without having to set up another server such as NFS), remote storage of artifacts in MLflow Tracking is non-existent.
Thank you for interacting with this issue! Removing the stale label!

I encountered this problem too. I use many docker containers to run e.g. a Spark environment and a volume to mount the project code into the Spark container. The paths to the mlruns folder are different for the host and the container in consequence. 
Unfortunately, mlflow saves absolute paths in the meta.yaml files and the mlflow never finds the artefacts.
I thought I can fix that with running a central tracking server in a container and log artefacts via the tracking server but the log_model behaviour was not as I expected and I am still looking for a way to use mlflow to manage my artefacts centralised without another sftp server or s3 etc.
I guess there are two issues at least for my use-case:

1. missing http protocol for log_model to upload models to a central tracking server
1. relative paths in meta.yml to share mlruns more easily

> I am still looking for a way to use mlflow to manage my artefacts centralised without another sftp server or s3 etc.

I eventually gave up looking (and you probably should as well:) and embraced the future as envisaged by Databricks - of rampant microservises architecture... It required as many as 3 different servers... and given the one-server-per-container rule, I have 3 containers as well:
1) metrics and params are stored in an SQL database, and I used MariaDB (`bitnami/mariadb`) - do not skip this one, as for performance reasons this should be the default option (I ended up increasing worker timeouts to 5 minutes and it was still not enough for default completely non-scalable metrics/params storage in text files)!
2) artifacts, including models, are uploaded to an S3 bucket, I used minIO (`bitnami/minio`) - it could be also probably achieved with NFS, but I would have to wait for / beg the cluster admin to set up appropriate PV's for me, so no, there are safer options these days and as a bonus of setting up minIO  you will gain a nice file transfer tool with a web interface a la Dropbox and even a method of exchanging large files directly between containers (e.g. with the `minio` python package),
3) `mflow server` runs in a dedicated container with access to credentials to both db and S3; and all these access details can be setup with either env vars recognized by mlflow or passed to mlflow server using its startup options in CMD section of your Dockerfile) (`mirekphd/ml-mlflow` - that's a custom one - enjoy:)

What I will have to probably do for security reasons is to add a 4th container with reverse proxy such as `bitnami/nginx` because authorization is another feature missing here... Oh, and I'm not affiliated with Bitnami, it's just that they have constistently hmm, rooted out root from their containers (and so should the official Docker images), so can be run with high UIDs and all capabilities dropped (such are my security constraints for all containers, including dev ones).
This issue has been automatically marked as stale because it has not had recent activity. It will be closed if no further activity occurs. Thank you for your contributions.
Thank you for interacting with this issue! Removing the stale label!

Hi folks, the source of confusion here appears to be the fundamental lack of support for proxying artifact uploads through the MLflow server. We're tracking this issue in #629 and would absolutely welcome designs for this capability. For now, I'm going to close this issue as a duplicate of #629 - please feel free to continue the discussion / contribute implementation ideas there!
